snippet.textDisplay: I’ve never been so affected by the passing of a celebrity, this has hit me so hard.  I remember hearing Spirit of the radio and loving that, then heard The Trees on a compilation album and I was hooked. Bought all their albums and saw them several times in the UK and their music has been the soundtrack of my life for many years. As lots of people have commented, “just celebrate the fact that he was with us” and  enjoy what he has given us. The earth is several billion years old, be thankful you were born at a time to listen to Rush👍

snippet.textDisplay: To quote a friend, "what a cruel end to such a creative life“. I only saw them twice, but they are still a staple in the soundtrack of my life. "Caress of Steel“ when I lost my dad, (I was 17), and everything that they’d done and were doing when I had a spinal cord injury. That was over 25 years ago, but I still listen to RUSH almost every day. I’m Canadian and take great pride in the fact that they are, too...that’s not really important though, because music has no boundaries. Here’s to the Peart family,  his friends, and the legions of RUSH fans all over the world, who feel like we’ve lost a friend.

snippet.textDisplay: One common thread that connects everyone's comments about the band has been how Canadian-ly polite Mister's Pratt, Dirk and Lerxst were/are. I grew and still live just outside of Detroit and I first heard Rush when a Windsor (?) radio station across the Detrot River, CJOM, played the 1st album. At the time the local stations didn't cover new talent or the emerging glam scene from England and New York. (NY Dolls, Bowie, Eno, Roxy, SAHB, Mike McGeer, Mott the Hoople, etc. Gave us an excuse to go to across the border into another "territory".- and to meet "better people, better food, better BEER") So Detroit, Cleveland and several other Great Lakes-industrial towns became early roosts for the band to visit. Thus access to the band was easier then than when they became single-act bill performers. I met them several times, and got to play/help intonate Alex's 355 and the Pyramid custom build. The owner/manager, Paul "Cowboy" Smith was a friend of my oldest brother owned and ran Pyramid Guitars. And their was other times, but that is another "story/comment for another time.  I got to meet Neil when during the Hemispheres tour, he did a rare interview at a local rock station. When he finished, he was cordial in answering questions from everyone and nobody fawned over him-true Rush fans! I asked him questions that our drummer wanted to ask him about his kit. And this was the all analog one. I love saying the word "glockenspiel". He signed my poster that came with the record. We all thanked him and he replied "See you guys at the show". When he got into the car, he opened a brief case to put away a manila envelope, and at that precise moment at least a 20 or more joints flew into the window and into the briefcase and his lap. He and the driver (Skip or Liam) starting laughing and Neil was just like "Oh wow- you guys are so generous!" "Thank You" in several languages, and "The crew will be happy.", etc. They pulled away and came to a stop after a few seconds and the driver rightfully put the briefcase in the trunk!  And Neil was riding in incognito-no hoi-palloi limo. We all kind of snickered at a slightly rusty early 1970's unibody construction oil burner. You could tell that  it was a unibody because it must of been in an accident or slid into a curb or snow drift. It was "dog trotting" because from behind you could see all 4 tires. Then at the concert when Geddy went to intro "Passage To Bangkok"-as "their Public Safety Announcement", Alex interrupted with "Neil would like to dedicate the song to everyone at this afternoon's  radio interview"  That was so cool! Where ever in JLA we (the fans that went there) were probably saying "Wow! That was ME!! From one of our heroes - that will forever remain in our memories.

snippet.textDisplay: Have you ever noticed the composition quality of their music and compare it with earlier composers?   As an example, they tend to change, and only as an example, lets says every 10 to 20 bars, then then  totally skews in a new direction.    I noticed similar styles with, for instance  Victor Young, who did the sound track for Around the World in 80 Days (1956).    Same thing.  (of course different genre)  It is just an observation that not many musicians did that on that level, as Rush did. (in this time period)

Thank you for this touching remembrance... I hadn't seen the News and it was very shocking when I saw it for the first time on here... The music and legacy will live on Sincere condolences to the family and all friends and fans.

''I strip away the old debris
That hides a shining car
A brilliant red Barchetta
From a better vanished time
I fire up the willing engine
Responding with a roar
Tires spitting gravel
I commit my weekly crime''

From 'Red Barchetta'  I'll always think of Neil when play this in my car

snippet.textDisplay: I had many drumming influences growing up. As a child I obsessed about Gene Krupa and Buddy Rich, even meeting the latter in my teens, but it was always Neil Peart who inspired me the most. I idolised the man, and tried so hard to emulate his playing (failing miserably of course!). It is so sad that he has gone, and hard to process. Much love to Alex and Geddy as they proceed through life without one of the greatest drummers of all time. RIP Neil Peart.

snippet.textDisplay:
My condolences on Neil's passing/home-going to Family Friends. Alex and Geddy and of course us Fans.... I've been a fan for a long time I think since 79 so Neil was like an older brother to me.
A very nice and humble guy. (I loved it when he said he learned a great lesson for not making it in England etc. Because he learned how to work (regular jobs) and make a living just like everyone else)... Who talks so honestly?
Once after a concert he sent his drumsticks to this kid who was standing up on balcony with his dad. I donno about that kid but it made my day...
Such a nice n awesome guy. I think first and foremost his lyrics n of course the sound attracted me to stay n follow Rush for all these years... I know the great n high class lyrics made me feel good about it n so I turned on so many ppl to Rush.
I'll miss Neil till I see him again . Meanwhile I listen n watch as much Rush as I can handle.
P.S. I'm glad he's with his daughter and other loved ones now but still we'll miss him.

snippet.textDisplay:
My girlfriend sent me a text when I was out getting dinner (at Wendys) her text said this: “OMG Neil Peart died” my response (I’ll clean it up) “
R U KIDDING??????? Oh fudge” I just recently got into Rush bought all the old albums under 10.00. First album I bought new was I believe “Snakes and Arrows” 2007. And it’s still one of my favorite albums of the 2000s my favorite album are Fairwell to Kings and Hemispheres due to I am a Genesis fan as well and those 2 albums have that Rush/Genesis sound in my opinion. Long songs. Then between hemisphere and Permanent Waves is like The Lamb lies down on Broadway and Trick of the Tail. Don’t get me wrong I enjoy all Rush albums however I didn’t get their covers record. All albums were great in their own way. I am one of those people who like only “originals” on albums. They play them in concert I’m cool with that. Never had the chance to see them live I regret that now. Anyway Rush was and will be one of my favorite bands of all times. Enough ranting. Thanks for reading. R.I.P. Professor🙏🏻 THANK YOU RICK FOR POSTING THIS.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thanks for your piece and respects for Mr. Peart. When I was playing drums in high school in the 1980s, Neil was the standard for me. Thoughtful, entertaining, technically proficient, and still not showy somehow.
The drummer Allison Miller talks and teaches about drumming for the song. It is in this moment that I realize that Neil Peart drummed as the song. Great drummers like Moon and Copeland (and Krupa for that matter) had the quality of playing with the singer as much as any other instrument. Neil Peart was a step beyond that because he was the architect of the lyrics and you can hear how his drumming intertwined with the story he told heard through Geddy's vocals. Never was there a better rock trio than Lee, Lifeson, and Peart to bring stories to life on a wave of sound. The music world (more than just the drumming segment) is so much better and more magically full for Mr. Peart. R.I.P. Neil...you moved as all.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for coming on immediately about this even though you both were obviously struggling for words. I really hope you decide to put together a special video that would at least hit the highlights of what he gave us all in terms of his art.

snippet.textDisplay: I know Neil wouldnt have been comfortable with it, but he was my hero.  He isnt just my favourite drummer but my all time favourite musician.  Second place isnt close.   Not just for his playing, his teaching and various outlets as a writer.  Ive been a huge Rush fan since 1985 and he was a gateway to so many other musicians as the guys alluded to in the video.  He loved to talk about his influences and about music that moved him as well.  Im so grateful to have had the chance to see Rush multiple times.  It was always an extraordinary experience shared with friends and family.  He will be missed but he left us an incredible legacy.

snippet.textDisplay: Rick, I am a few years older(1958) than you. I discovered RUSH with the release of 2112 thru a Milwaukee hard rock station at the time, WZMF. Went out and bought it the next day. It is one of maybe 4 albums which changed the direction of my music listening to the hard arena rock genre. It engulfed my being to its core. Musically they as a band were unique and never truly copied, in style or lyrically. They never looked down at us the fan with simplistic messaging. They mattered. In opposition to 'Limelight' I wish I was a long awaited friend of theirs, knowing them well enough to be able to buy them a drink and drink it with them. Neil is the 1st of those in our generation we listened that we have lost that does hurt inside. We are better because these guys had the guts to chase their dream, grab it by the balls, and do it their way. Thanks guys, see you in the next life.

snippet.textDisplay:
I can't add much to what's already been said here, except to say what wonderful and caring bandmates and people Neil Peart had around him. They knew he was dying for 3 years, yet respected and loved him so much they kept it private. That is real love.

I thank Mr. Peart for the gifts he gave us of his art, his intellect and his humanity.

I remember the warning he and Rush left us with 'Witch Hunt.' We must always be aware of intolerance and hate. Only by thinking, reaching out, caring and loving each other can we make this Earth a better place for humanity and all living things.

snippet.textDisplay: This one hurts. It hurts as much as Bowie's death hurt. Some people wonder why we take it this hard. It's not like we were part of their inner circle (at least for most of us). But we kind of know them, the art they shared is intimate, they are brave enough to share their inner fears, hopes and dreams. And when we lose an icon, a legend of our youth, we are faced with our own mortality. I always fall back on the words of the late George Harrison in times like this: "All things must pass. All things must pass away." Nothing is permanent. No one lives forever. But for the art they share, we will have them as long as we live...and as long as people come to know the art and appreciate it, it will last.  Goodbye Mr. Peart, and thank you for sharing your time with us.

snippet.textDisplay: As a proud Canadian, a drummer and a lifelong Rush fan, I’m devastated at the passing of Neil Peart. He was the ultimate personification of musical talent. His legacy will endure through the ages. I am eternally grateful for his immense contribution to music and for being an major influence in my formative years as a young drummer. RIP Neil. “The proper function of man is to live, not to exist. I shall not waste my days in trying to prolong them. I shall use my time.” - Neil Peart

snippet.textDisplay: Most people incarnate, and leave very little impact, they have children perhaps, their name is carved on a tombstone, but eventually their name fades into history. Neil Peart, that name will truly echo in eternity, uttered with reverence for time immemorial, his legacy lives on, Imagine the Rush tribute concert that happens in 2112. He made a mark equal of great figures of history, whatever reason he was put on this planet, he fulfilled that purpose, and then some. I hope Neil, that the outpouring of millions of people around the globe, these words of condolence, these messages of love and utmost respect, find their way to you, in whatever reality you now inhabit, as a magnificent wave of pure conscious love. I hope your destination is as magical and wondrous as that which you gave to us. Farewell, to Kings.....

snippet.textDisplay:
Like Rick I am profoundly saddened by this news. I grew up as a British army child in Germany in the 70’s and early 80’s and my brother introduced me to Rush with Hemispheres. Moving around a lot the comfort that he and I got from just being able to sit down with our vinyl LPs and listen to the amazing trio and read the lyrics on the album notes gave us hours of discussion about what they meant and how they affected us at a basic level. Even as young kids we knew that this band were something special and it was a perfect melding of outstanding musicians coupled to deep, meaningful and sometimes just perfect song lyrics.

The professor touched so many lives, influenced so many people and made two snotty army brats very happy, for that I thank him from the bottom of my soul

“When all around is madness and there’s no safe port in view, I long to turn my path homeward and stop a while with you”

RIP Neil
snippet.textOriginal:
Like Rick  I am profoundly saddened by this news. I grew up as a British army child in Germany in the 70’s and early 80’s and my brother introduced me to Rush with Hemispheres. Moving around a lot the comfort that he and I got from just being able to sit down with our vinyl LPs and listen to the amazing trio and read the lyrics on the album notes gave us hours of discussion about what they meant and how they affected us at a basic level. Even as young kids we knew that this band were something special and it was a perfect melding of outstanding musicians coupled to deep, meaningful and sometimes just perfect song lyrics.  

The professor touched so many lives, influenced so many people and made two snotty army brats very happy, for that I thank him from the bottom of my soul

“When all around is madness and there’s no safe port in view, I long to turn my path homeward and stop a while with you”

RIP Neil

snippet.textDisplay:
Working Man was my first favorite Rush Song too! Funny and heartwarming story about the fan letter. All the outpouring of grief and appreciation not only on this video and in this comment section, which is substantial but ACROSS the music world from Styx to Foo Fighters, to Tool, to thousands of other artists, it's so very clear Neil Peart was such a positive influence on so many people. To see these heartfelt messages of tribute and of goodbye is a form of beauty in the face of tragedy. During Rush's career they were often met with obstacles. Labels didn't want to sign them, radio stations didn't want to play them, and fans were made fun for liking them too. It was often ridiculed as "Nerd Rock", "Loser Music", or "What the virgin smart kids listen too". I've heard it all in my time but the fact is: Rush is one of the top 5 rock bands of all time bar none. Often called the Canadian Led Zeppelin (while many would argue they were better than Zeppelin) Every single member of the band was ultra talented but Neil Peart in my humble opinion, was the best of them all. Not only was he the greatest drummer alive, he wrote the lyrics. I'll leave you with my favorite Neil Peart lyric:


"And the men who hold high places
Must be the ones to start
To mold a new reality
Closer to the Heart"

As true now as it was then. It's what I call an Evergreen lyric, it will never grow old. Much like the discography of Rush.


Rest in peace Neil. A great lyricist, great drummer, a great human. You will be missed, but never forgotten.

snippet.textDisplay: The fans' outpouring of grief over Neil Peart makes me cringe-and I am an avowed 35 year fan of him and Rush. The artists, agents, executives and managers at the highest level of the business are mercenary, cut throat, greedy and soulless and these are the moments when it is exposed yet the fans can't see it.  People are saying that Rush are 'like a family' and that they won't tour without NP. Well we'll just wait and see. I wouldn't bet the farm on it. Just like Steely Dan went straight out on tour within weeks of Walter Becker dying you'll find Lee and Lifeson are a lot less sentimental than you expect. They will probably be out on tour with a 'replacement' as there's plenty who are capable, Minneman/Blundell/Gavin Harrison etc. The fans will be forced to accept it and the PR machine/Press will say they possibly sound 'even better'. Toto, The Who have replaced 'irreplaceable' drummers and Queen, Fleetwood Mac, The Eagles have even done the same with iconic vocalists in Mercury/Buckingham/Frey. Just red pilling you folks so you don't have to be so shocked when it happens. Come back and thank me later.

snippet.textDisplay:
Count me among the rest of us who are profoundly sad and heartbroken. Neil is the reason I picked up drumsticks as a kid. I spent countless hours trying to play along (and thinking I could), but I’d usually just stop playing and bask in the awesomeness. I still do. But, I’m still trying, and he would appreciate that. He said’ “What is a master but a master student?”

I credit him for my love of the drum kit, and also for influencing my appreciation for freedom of though, and love of reading.

As you guys said - what a hugely likable person he was, above all. There have been and still are many drummers that are insanely talented, but not many at all with his intelligence, humility, and SENSE OF HUMOR. The man was very, very funny - he just didn’t show it much.

“Limelight” pretty much defined his attitude toward fame, and you really can’t blame him, as talented as he was.

The boy is right, and as easy as it is to fall into grief, his music and talent and words will live on forever, and we should celebrate that.

RIP, Professor. You are missed.

snippet.textDisplay:
When I was 3 years old, I got my first drum set for Christmas. When I first sat down at it, I didn't play a thing, I just sat their staring at it. This went on for five minutes until my parents asked me what I was doing. I said I was imagining I was Neil Peart, getting ready to start his next solo. When I heard of the news of Neil's passing, I immediately went back to my music room, and sat down at that same drum set. As I did that, I imagined Neil doing the same thing up in the sky, starting his next solo.
Neil Peart was the reason that I started playing drums.
Thank you for posting this, Rick.

snippet.textDisplay: Back in the late '70s, I was a youngster in junior high, and had been taking drum lessons for 3-4 years. My older brother got the Rush Archives album for Christmas, and I couldn't believe what I was hearing... a myriad of rudimentary fills with rolls, flams, paradiddles, hi hat barks, double kicks, all arranged in endlessly creative patterns against hard rock music. It was so innovative and so groundbreaking at the time, and this was when Rush was a power rock trio without keyboards... props to Neil for defining his own "hard prog rock" sound and taking rock drumming to entirely different level. I believe he changed rock drumming forever.

May I and my children have long memories.
snippet.textOriginal:
Both my wife and I were shocked to hear this news.  I can tell that we are all in the same position; many friends were hopeful of another set of shows or something... I choose to be sad and mourn.  There is a piece of my childhood that has now gone, but the work he has produced far outweighs the sorrow I feel at this moment.  
May I and my children have long memories.

Rick and Jack: This had to be difficult to do, but both of you handled this well. A very good tribute.
Neil is upstairs with his wife and daughter, while jamming with Freddy Gruber.
RIP Neil: It was always a privilege watching Rush in concert.
"Living in a fisheye lens,
Caught in the camera eye,
I have no heart to lie,
I can't pretend a stranger is a long awaited friend."

snippet.textDisplay:
The beat moves on even though he’s gone.
I’ve been a long time fan of Rush, but have really grown to love the music the passed 10 or 15 years, because of my sons, they have really embraced it and because of that they had to go to concerts! So they took me along and have been fortunate enough to see there last 3 tours in the passed 10 year’s.
Rest easy Neil.❤️

snippet.textDisplay: I was sad when Petty, Bowie, Cornel died but this hit me harder than any of those.  Saturday after hearing the news I fought tears all the way home as I had Rush blasting from my car.  I remember buying Rush Retrospective as a teenager and life was forever changed.  Been a massive fan ever since.  Thanks for the video.  I’m sure the family appreciates the love.  I think Geddy Lee said to contribute to a Cancer charity of our choice.

snippet.textDisplay:
Rick, thanks for posting this video. You echoed what and how so many of us (younger and not so young) feel about this loss, how Rush was with a lot of us through high school. college, young adulthood and beyond, and how profound of a loss this is. Especially difficult the thought of Neil losing his mental prowess through the horrible illness of brain cancer.

Condolences to his family, Alex and Geddy and to all of us to have been lucky enough to enjoy Rush through the years.
